item.title: By: Tom Nichols
item.dc:creator: Tom Nichols
item.description: <p>I have to say I like the Outlook client. We use Outlook 2003 and Exchange 2003. Type ahead is great, I like being able to recall messages if I forget to attach something, and the interface is fairly intuitive.<br/><br/><br/><br/>That said, I must admit that I don't use it offline at all (not worth the hassle IMHO), We do have OWA (Outlook Web Access) running in our environment, and it's 2003 also. That makes being remote much easier. I also don't do a lot of filing away in folders, etc. I read my e-mail, save attachments off somewhere if I need to keep them, and delete the rest. I don't get complex with it.<br/><br/><br/><br/>Tom</p>
item.content:encoded:
I have to say I like the Outlook client. We use Outlook 2003 and Exchange 2003. Type ahead is great, I like being able to recall messages if I forget to attach something, and the interface is fairly intuitive.

That said, I must admit that I don’t use it offline at all (not worth the hassle IMHO), We do have OWA (Outlook Web Access) running in our environment, and it’s 2003 also. That makes being remote much easier. I also don’t do a lot of filing away in folders, etc. I read my e-mail, save attachments off somewhere if I need to keep them, and delete the rest. I don’t get complex with it.

Tom

item.title: By: Chris Doig
item.dc:creator: Chris Doig
item.description: <p>I recently spent 9 months working at a client who used Outlook. One thing I really didn't like about Outlook was the inability to put one message in multiple folders without copying it. Then the fact that I couldn't full text index my mail. Apparently you can enable mail indexing on the server, but that never seems to get done. I tried the Google plug in to help search my mail, but I couldn't get satisfactory results. Of course if a message was in multiple folders, a search would return multiple hits.</p><p>Another great thing about Notes is soft deletions. Notes automatically empties my trash after X hours. Outlook either prompted me every time I closed it, or the trash would fill up and my generous 12 Mb (yes twelve!) would overflow every few days prompting more annoying messages.</p><p>I use Notes mail for my personal mailbox, and have done for years. I do, however, run a Notes server at home, which is not practical for most people (peer to peer replication would be great!). But I can take my mail file with me when I travel, and process my mail from a hotel room. Upon returning, everything is synched after replication. I works for me.</p><p>If any family or friends ask me about email, these days I always recommend an online service over a local mail client. You can get your mail from anywhere, and their spam filtering works so well I would never think of doing it in a client.</p>
item.content:encoded:
I recently spent 9 months working at a client who used Outlook. One thing I really didn’t like about Outlook was the inability to put one message in multiple folders without copying it. Then the fact that I couldn’t full text index my mail. Apparently you can enable mail indexing on the server, but that never seems to get done. I tried the Google plug in to help search my mail, but I couldn’t get satisfactory results. Of course if a message was in multiple folders, a search would return multiple hits.

Another great thing about Notes is soft deletions. Notes automatically empties my trash after X hours. Outlook either prompted me every time I closed it, or the trash would fill up and my generous 12 Mb (yes twelve!) would overflow every few days prompting more annoying messages.

I use Notes mail for my personal mailbox, and have done for years. I do, however, run a Notes server at home, which is not practical for most people (peer to peer replication would be great!). But I can take my mail file with me when I travel, and process my mail from a hotel room. Upon returning, everything is synched after replication. I works for me.

If any family or friends ask me about email, these days I always recommend an online service over a local mail client. You can get your mail from anywhere, and their spam filtering works so well I would never think of doing it in a client.
